story.storykicker: A case of forgery and cheating was lodged against unidentified agents on Saturday, May 28, 2016 by Mumbai police, after they received complaints from over 66 parents.
story.storybody:
A case of forgery and cheating was lodged against unidentified agents on Saturday, May 28, 2016 by Mumbai police, after they received complaints from over 66 parents.

What was the complaint?

  • The parents, who were seeking admission for their wards under the Right to Education Act, said the agents had charged them huge sum of money and had provided them with bogus income certificates
  • Gayatri Gupta, a parent from Malad east seeking admission for her son, said that she had even shelled out Rs 3,000 to an agent last year after he promised to provide the certificate in a couple of days
  • "He (the agent) said the process of getting an income certificate would take 15-20 days but he could get it done in a couple of days," she said, according to The Indian Express
  • She said she had submitted the certificate online during admissions last year but realised that it was fake after the school told her in April. "I was told by the school management that my son's admission had been cancelled because the income certificate we had submitted was bogus," she said
  • According to the police, the parents were seeking admission for their wards through the 25 per cent seats reserved for the Economically Weaker Sections (EWS) under RTE at five ICSE-board schools run by the Goenka Education Trust in Goregaon East
  • Inspector Ravi Adane stated that the parents got the income certificates, declaring that they belong to the EWS, through agents and had submitted those at the schools while seeking admission of their wards.
  • "The schools sent the certificates to the tehsildar office for scrutiny. But the tehsildar said the certificates were bogus," he said
  • Rubina Patel, another parent, revealed that she took the help of an agent in the year 2013 after observing that the children of her neighbours in the E-ward slums were able to successfully secure admission through him
  • "The agent had a reputation for getting income certificates in time in the area. I came to know about him through word-of-mouth and later sought his help for my daughter's admission to nursery in 2013. I only found out that the certificate was fake this year," said Patel.
  • "The schools are not responsible for the certificates. When we asked the parents, they said they do not know who the agents are," he said.
As of now, the police are on the lookout for the agents.

story.shortheadline: EWS admissions: Mumbai police issues FIR against agents for issuing fake income certificates to parents
